## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:


```{r data}
# input: WXS sample id, TCGA clinical information file
# output: a csv file with columns = ["id","status","time", "age", "clinical_stage"]
# id	survival_status	survival_days	age_days	clinical_stage	binary_sig3	exposure_sig3
a <- "abc"
b <- "de"
paste("li",b,"fg", sep="")
```

```{r survival}
library(survminer)
library(survival)

#id_type <- "WXS"
#id_type <- "MSK"
id_type <- "MSK-MSK"
data_type <- "assignments"

# Load data
tcga_ov <- read.csv(paste("/Users/yuexichen/Downloads/lrgr_file/mskfiles/final-TCGA-OV-", id_type, "-survial-analysis-",  data_type, ".tsv", sep = ''),sep='\t')
# Specify data type: MSK, WXS or MSK-MSK

if(data_type == "MSK-MSK"){
  tcga_ov$new_binary_sig3 <- as.numeric(tcga_ov$exposure_sig3 > 0.001)
}
# Remove NAs
# 1 is censored and 2 is dead
tcga_ov <- tcga_ov[!(tcga_ov$survival_status == 0),]
# Fit survival curves
fit <- survfit(Surv(survival_days, survival_status) ~ binary_sig3, data = tcga_ov)
# Drawing curves
ggsurvplot(fit, conf.int = TRUE, pval = TRUE) + ggtitle(paste("Survival analysis for TCGA-OV-", id_type, "-",data_type, sep=''))
```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r cox}
# Transform age to years
tcga_ov$age_year <- tcga_ov$age_days/365
fit2 <- coxph(Surv(survival_days, survival_status) ~ binary_sig3 + age_year + clinical_stage , data=tcga_ov)
ggforest(fit2, data =tcga_ov)
```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.
